subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to write effective tests?
msgSnippet: So said  Dave Astels   on  2003-01-24 ... Seconded. I suppose the fact that people are writing effective and sufficient tests without BDUF
messageBody:
So said Dave Astels <dave@...> on 2003-01-24
--------------------

>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, santhu ps <sps19742001@y...> wrote:
>> Hi all,
>>
>> With respect to the question 'How to write
>> effective
>> tests".I want to point out one related question
>> also that "How we will conclude that the test cases
>> that we designed is suficient".
>
>If you're using JUnit, you can use Jester and a code coverage tool
>like Clover to give you feedback on what's not being tested, and
>what's not being tested precisely enough.
>
>> Effectiveness and sufficiency of test cases what we
>> designed can ensure that only if we are designing the
>> test cases in a formal methodological manner.
>
>Sorry, I don't buy that.

Seconded. I suppose the fact that people are writing effective and
sufficient tests without BDUF doesn't count, eh? :)
